poem:
"In Cryptic Puzzle's Return"

Whirl of black and white squares, riddles interlaced,
Inky labyrinth wherein we chase
Echoes of a Sphinx, once masked, unerased.
Phantom of the crossword, graced
By television's fleeting space,
Crafts new puzzles in Dracula's embrace.
This September night, word-master's face
Revealed in the quiet ordinary place.
Each clue a poetic embrace,
Better to escape than erase.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Better to escape than delete’ – Guardian crossword setter Sphinx returns Sphinx’s first puzzle appeared in 2017 and solvers were delightfully flabbergasted to see it appear in a fictional context on the same night’s television. The programme was Inside No 9, but its world’s fictional setter was able to create puzzles in other worlds: witness 2020’s Dracula. Sphinx – AKA writer and performer Steve Pemberton – made a quiet reappearance last September with a puzzle". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
